properties.name: Zanzibar, Tanzania
properties.type: The Monkey, the Shark, and the Washerman’s Donkey
properties.location: Island of Unguja, colloquially known as Zanzibar Island, is located off the coast of Tanzania and is just south of Kenya.
properties.facts: This is a myth about the freindship and betrayal of a monkey and a shark. The tale begins with the blossoming of freindship between the mokey and the shark. They monkey would drop down fruit for the shark to eat, and the shark eventually comes to invite the monkey to a feast under the sea. However, when the monkey learns of the sharks true intentions to take the monkey's heart, the monkey strikes back with a trick to get the shark to bring him back to the tree. This story does not portray sharks or monkeys as evil, and shines a neutral light on the both of them.

properties.name: Martha's Vineyard
properties.location: Off the coast of Cape Cod, Massachusetts lives the Island of Martha's Vineyard.
properties.facts: Steven Spielberg's infamous movie Jaws is set in this New England vacation haven. Jaws is a movie chronicaling the tale of a massive killer shark that terrorizes the residents of a seaside town. This movie paints the shark in a terrible light, showing it as mysterious, muderous, and malicous. This movie came out on June 20th, 1975, just in time for the summer festivities of the beach. This movie is regarded as one of the best horror films of all time, and is one of the largest phenomena of pop culture influencing environmental health that we have on record..

properties.name: Atlantic Slave Trade
properties.type: Tactics of Fear Through the Use of Sharks
properties.location: The location chosen for this topic is Maryland, as it was the hub of the slave trade in the United States in 1660.
properties.facts: The Atlantic Slave Trade has a lot of untaught horrors which are still being recovered, one of which involved the fear tactic of sharks for slaves on boats. Transporters would throw slaves overboard, sometimes baiting the water first, for a variety of reasons, including food shortages, disciplinary actions, sadistic pleasure, setting of examples, etc. This ingrained a fear of sharks in not only enslaved culture, but in the culture of the slave owners and citizens who heard the tales of the boats. This reinforced in society the mysticism of sharks and the power that they held. Many artists took these events and accounts and made works based off of the trauma and fear these people thrown overboard experienced.
properties.imageCaption: Rendering of Slaves Being Thrown Overboard to Hungry Sharks
properties.source: "History from below the water line: Sharks and the Atlantic slave trade" by Marcus Rediker

properties.name: Kāmohoaliʻi
properties.type: Shark Diety and Protector of Humans
properties.location: Located in Hawaii and is said to roam all of the Islands
properties.facts: This spirit is said to have it's origins in leading sailors back to their homes. Kāmohoaliʻi would shake his tale, and the fishermen and sailors would give him offerings in order to get safe and quick passage. Kāmohoaliʻi is still a prevelant shark spirit in Hawaiian culture, and is known as a powerful and benevolent entity. There are still many who worship this shark for its great service to the poeple of the islands. Kāmohoaliʻi is also said to have lead the original Hawaiians to the islands..
properties.imageCaption: The Journey of Pele, Painted by Herb Kawainui Kane
properties.source: <i>Hawaiian Folk Tales</> by Thomas G. Thrum

properties.name: The Leg Of Nohi Abassi
properties.location: The location chosen for this myth is Brasil, even though it is a popular myth in Guiana as well. Brasil was chosen because it was where the myth originated, and then the myth transfered over after the colinization of Guiana.
properties.facts: This myth shows the power that sharks can posess, and paints them as easily swayed. The Leg Of Nohi Abassi is an explanation for the creation of Orion's Belt, which was thought to be the leg of the Hunter Nohi Abassi. Nohi had grown annoyed with his mother-in-law so much so that he had trained a shark to hunt and eat her. When the mother-in-law caught wind of this, she turned her other daughter into a shark and trained her to harm Abassi. When the time was right, the sister sawed of Abassi's leg with her teeth, which then became Orion's Belt.

properties.name: The Myth of Lamia
properties.type: The Story of Hera's Jealousy and Lamia's Revenge
properties.facts: Lamia was the daughter of Posiden. Lamia began getting close with Zues, and an affair ensued. This enraged Hera when she found out about it, and as revenge, she decided to steal all of Lamia's children and murder them. Lamia was distraught, and to help her get back at Hera, Zues decided to turn her into a ferocious shark with the intent of murdering innocent children to get back at Hera. She will forever roam the waters in search of children to kill in order to hurt Hera. This myth paints sharks as violent and malicous. It portrays them as blood hungry, and influenced people into thinking that all sharks were bad and out to eat their children.
properties.source: Dictionary of Greek and Roman Biography and Mythology, Volume 2 By Sir William Smith
